transcript:
Therapist: Let's start by reviewing your experience with the homework assignments from our last session. How did you find the process of creating your personalized CBT toolbox and coping cards? Were there any challenges or insights that stood out to you?

Patient: Creating the toolbox and coping cards was actually quite helpful. It felt good to have a tangible reminder of the skills I've learned. I did struggle a bit with identifying the most relevant thoughts and strategies to include. There's so much we've covered, and I wanted to make sure I captured the most important points.

Therapist: It's great that you found the process helpful, and it's completely normal to feel a bit overwhelmed when trying to distill all the information we've covered. Remember, your toolbox and coping cards can be living documents that you update and refine over time as you continue to practice and gain new insights. Let's take a moment to review what you've included so far. Can you share a few of the key thoughts and strategies you've written down?

Patient: Sure. One of the main thoughts I included was "Progress, not perfection." It's a reminder to challenge my all-or-nothing thinking and celebrate small victories. I also included a coping card about self-care, with strategies like taking a walk in nature, calling a friend, and practicing deep breathing. For the toolbox, I included examples of thought records and continuum thinking exercises we've done together.

Therapist: Those are excellent choices, Alexis. I can see how those thoughts and strategies directly address some of the core challenges we've been working on, like perfectionism and self-care. As you continue to practice these skills, you'll likely find that certain ones become more automatic and integrated into your daily life. That's the goal of therapy – to equip you with tools that you can use independently, even after our sessions have ended.

Patient: That makes sense. I guess I'm just worried about maintaining my progress without the regular check-ins and guidance from our sessions.

Therapist: It's completely understandable to feel some anxiety about ending therapy. That's why we're focusing on creating a solid plan for maintaining your progress. One helpful tool is a relapse prevention plan, which outlines specific steps you can take if you start to notice your symptoms worsening or if you face a particularly challenging situation. We can work together to identify early warning signs and create a personalized plan that feels manageable for you.

Patient: That sounds really helpful. I like the idea of having a concrete plan to fall back on if I start to struggle.

Therapist: Absolutely. We'll also discuss how you can continue to access support after our sessions end, whether that's through your social network, self-care practices, or even periodic "booster" sessions if needed. Remember, ending therapy doesn't mean you're on your own. It's about transitioning to a new phase of your mental health journey, where you take the lead in applying the skills you've learned.

Patient: I appreciate that perspective. It feels less daunting when I frame it as a transition rather than an endpoint.

Therapist: That's a great way to look at it, Alexis. Let's take a moment to check in on how you're feeling about all of this. What emotions are coming up for you as we discuss ending therapy and maintaining your progress?

Patient: I feel a mix of emotions, to be honest. I'm proud of the progress I've made and excited to apply what I've learned, but I'm also nervous about facing challenges without the regular support of our sessions. I guess I'm feeling a bit uncertain about what the future holds.

Therapist: It's completely normal to feel a mix of emotions as we approach the end of therapy. It's a significant transition, and it's okay to feel both excited and nervous about what comes next. Remember, these feelings don't have to be all-or-nothing. You can feel proud and uncertain at the same time. That's the beauty of continuum thinking – it allows for a more nuanced and balanced perspective.

Patient: That's a good point. I don't have to be 100% confident to move forward. It's okay to have some doubts and concerns.

Therapist: Exactly. And as we continue to work on your relapse prevention plan and discuss strategies for maintaining your progress, hopefully, some of those concerns will feel more manageable. Remember, you've already demonstrated tremendous resilience and growth throughout our work together. You have the skills and the strength to navigate this next phase, even if it feels challenging at times.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. That means a lot to me. I know I have the tools, it's just a matter of continuing to use them and trust in the process.

Therapist: You're welcome, Alexis. I have complete faith in your ability to continue this work independently. As we move forward in today's session, let's start to outline your relapse prevention plan. We can identify specific early warning signs to watch out for, such as changes in sleep patterns, increased irritability, or persistent negative thoughts. Then, we can brainstorm concrete steps you can take if you notice these signs, like reaching out to a friend, engaging in self-care activities, or reviewing your coping cards.
